title: R41142
content: According to the U.S. Department of Education data, public education spent $36.8 billion on construction and $3.3 billion on land and structures in FY2012. Colleges and universities completed $12.0 billion in construction in 2014. The federal government plays a role in financing school construction through indirect and direct support. This report examines school infrastructure needs. The report discusses the federal role in financing school infrastructure for K-12 public schools and higher education facilities. Data on school infrastructure condition and investment needs are limited and outdated, making it difficult to assess. There is no ongoing federal data collection on school conditions, but a one-time study in 2000 estimated costs for modernizations, renovations, and repairs for K-12 public school buildings. The estimated cost of repairs, renovations, and modernization required to bring 2012-2013 public school facilities into good condition was approximately $197 billion or $4.5 million per school. School infrastructure needs are affected by the age, physical condition, student population shifts, changes in school policies, expectations, technology, and instructional practices. For example, smaller class sizes may require additional space, computers may need rewiring, and science curriculum changes may necessitate new facilities. Increased science curriculum requirements may necessitate new laboratory facilities and rewiring classrooms. Postsecondary education institutions rely on land and facilities as tangible assets to support enrollment growth and technological advancements. Regular maintenance and renovation of facilities are essential for research and educational missions. Research universities may need an endowment equal to construction costs to maintain facilities. The National Science Foundation's biennial study shows that a significant portion of research space at colleges and universities required renovation or replacement in recent years. The costs for new construction, repair, and renovation of science and engineering research space in academic institutions increased from $9.9 billion in FY2010/FY2011 to $10.5 billion in FY2014/FY2015. Deferred projects costs rose from $21.3 billion in FY2011 to $22.0 billion in FY2015. The Educational Facilities Clearinghouse, supported by the Department of Education since 1997, provides resources for planning, designing, and maintaining educational facilities. Congress allocated $1 million for the clearinghouse in the FY2015 appropriations conference agreement. The federal government has historically played a role in financing school facilities through tax-exempt bonds. State and local governments issue these bonds to fund public projects, and certain private activities, allowing them to be issued at lower interest rates. Additionally, tax credit bonds are available, providing holders with a federal tax credit for a percentage of the bond's value for a limited time. During the Great Depression, the federal government funded school infrastructure through programs like the Works Progress Administration, which built and renovated thousands of schools. Impact Aid programs were also established to fund school construction in federally affected areas, areas impacted by federal activities, and facilities damaged by disasters. These programs provided equitable services to private school students from FY1989 to FY2001 in response to Supreme Court rulings. In the 1990s, efforts were made to increase federal assistance for school infrastructure improvements. The Education Infrastructure Act of 1994, part of the Improving America's Schools Act, aimed to provide federal aid for school renovation and construction but was never funded. FEMA has managed disaster assistance programs since 1992, with Congress enacting additional legislation for temporary programs in response to natural disasters. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2001 allocated $1.2 billion for school renovation, repair, and technology activities. Most of the funding went towards school facilities in specific LEAs, but the program was not permanently authorized and did not receive funding in subsequent years. In 2009, the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act authorized a one-time $54 billion for state renovation and construction. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 authorized a $54 billion State Fiscal Stabilization Fund for education, including the restoration of public school facilities. States were required to allocate a portion of the funds for K-12 construction but not for higher education facilities. Federal support for higher education facilities dates back to the 1857 Act for the Deaf and Blind institution, with subsequent appropriations for Howard University and the National Technical Institute for the Deaf. Various loan and grant programs have been authorized by Congress to aid in the construction, reconstruction, and renovation of educational facilities. The Higher Education Facilities Act of 1963 authorized loans for construction of academic facilities, with a revolving loan fund established by P.L. 89-429. The Education Amendments of 1972 provided annual interest grants and academic facilities loan insurance to assist in procuring loans for academic facilities. The Public Health Service Act, as amended by the Health Professions Educational Assistance Act of 1963, authorized grants for teaching facilities for health personnel and schools of nursing. The Higher Education Facilities Act of 1963 authorized grants for teaching facilities for health personnel and schools of nursing. Loan guaranties and interest subsidies were provided for construction, rehabilitation, and replacement of teaching facilities. Federal support for nursing school facilities was repealed by the Nurse Education Amendments of 1985. The Higher Education Facilities Act of 1963 authorized grants for undergraduate and graduate academic facilities to increase enrollment capacity at institutions of higher education. If a facility funded by these grants ceases to be used for academic purposes within 20 years, the federal government can recover a share of the grant. The Education Amendments of 1972 established a program for the establishment and expansion of community colleges. The Education Amendments of 1976 and 1980 amended programs for community colleges, providing funds for reconstruction, renovation, and modernization of facilities. The 1980 amendments repealed three existing facilities programs. The Higher Education Amendments of 1986 expanded grant funds for postsecondary institutions to improve facilities, comply with hazardous waste disposal requirements, enhance energy efficiency, provide advanced skill training programs, and preserve significant architecture. It also authorized the establishment of the College Construction Loan Insurance Association (Connie Lee). Connie Lee, a private corporation, succeeded the Academic Facilities Loan Insurance program to guarantee bonds, debentures, and loans for education facilities. Congress was concerned about deteriorating facilities affecting higher education quality and lack of access to capital for financially sound institutions. The U.S. Department of Education and Sallie Mae became significant shareholders of Connie Lee. The 1986 Amendments authorized Sallie Mae to finance higher education academic facilities. Connie Lee and Sallie Mae were privatized under the Omnibus Consolidated Appropriations Act, 1997. Reasons for privatizing Connie Lee included declining federal government share, success of other investors in providing loans, statutory limitations on Connie Lee's market expansion, and federal policy encouraging downsizing and privatizing. The Higher Education Amendments of 1992 replaced existing grant and loan programs with new ones, which were never funded. Loan programs have not issued new loans since FY1993, but collections and resolutions may continue through FY2030. The 1992 Amendments also authorized the Historically Black College and University Capital Financing program. The Higher Education Amendments of 1992 replaced existing grant and loan programs with new ones, which were never funded. Amendments also authorized the Historically Black College and University Capital Financing program to provide HBCUs with access to low-cost capital for school construction and renovation. Various federal allowances and programs offer support through grants, loans, or loan guarantees for eligible entities such as states, local governments, and postsecondary institutions. The Alaska Native Educational Equity, Support, and Assistance Act provides grants for educational needs of Alaska Natives. FY2014 and FY2015 appropriations are $31 million each. ED administers programs for charter school facilities support. The Per-Pupil Facilities Aid Programs provide competitive grants to states with charter school facilities aid programs, assisting charter schools with facility costs. California, the District of Columbia, Indiana, Minnesota, and Utah have received aid since FY2006. The Credit Enhancement for Charter School Facilities program aims to improve access to capital markets for charter school facilities financing. Funds are awarded on a competitive basis to public and nonprofit entities to help charter schools obtain facilities through purchase, lease, renovation, or construction. The State Charter Schools Facilities Incentive Grants program and the Credit Enhancement for Charter School Facilities program were removed from the Charter Schools program. The Charter Schools program supports planning, design, and initial implementation of charter schools. The Charter Schools' appropriation for FY2014 was $248 million, and for FY2015 it was $253 million. In FY2014, ED allocated $11 million to the Incentive Grants program and $12 million to the Credit Enhancement program. In FY2015, ED allocated $9 million to the Incentive Grants program and $14 million to the Credit Enhancement program. The Child Care Means Parents in School Program supports low-income parents in postsecondary education through campus-based child care services. Funds support child care and early childhood development services for low-income students pursuing postsecondary education. The appropriations for low-income students pursuing postsecondary education were $15 million in FY2014 and FY2015. Following disasters like Hurricane Katrina, aid was provided for K-12 and higher education facilities' construction and repair. The Historically Black College and University Capital Financing Program offers low-cost loans for infrastructure improvements at HBCUs, with financial insurance provided by the Secretary of Education. The designated bonding authority issues qualified bonds to provide loans to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) for various campus improvements. The loan and interest volume cap is $1.1 billion, but the Secretary can exceed this limit as per appropriations acts. Howard University, a private research university, receives federal support for construction and development. Howard University program provides support for construction, development, improvement, endowment, and maintenance of the university and hospital. The appropriations for Howard University and the hospital were $222 million each in FY2014 and FY2015. Impact Aid program compensates LEAs for lost revenue due to federal activities, including payments for construction and maintenance of school facilities. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) provides funds to states for the education of children with disabilities, including grants for school-aged children, infants, toddlers, and special education research. Part B funds can be used for equipment, construction, and facility alterations with the Secretary of Education's approval. Appropriations for IDEA were $1.3 billion in FY2014 and FY2015. The appropriations for Part B in FY2014 and FY2015 were each $11.5 billion, providing grants to eligible institutions of higher education for various activities. Eligible institutions must enroll a high proportion of needy and minority students, with criteria varying for each program. These programs allow for construction, maintenance, renovation, and improvement of instructional facilities. The Native Hawaiian Education Act (ESEA, Title VII-B) provides competitive grants for innovative education programs to assist Native Hawaiians, with appropriations totaling $521 million for FY2014 and $530 million for FY2015. Additional mandatory appropriations of $258 million in FY2014 and $236 million in FY2015 were provided by the SAFRA Act (P.L. 111-152). The act also authorizes the Native Hawaiian Education Council and island councils for program oversight. Gallaudet University, funded by the Department of Education of Hawaii, serves a predominantly Native Hawaiian student body. The university offers traditional undergraduate and graduate programs, as well as programs related to deafness. It operates the Laurent Clerc National Deaf Education Center, including the Kendall Demonstration Elementary School and the Model Secondary School for the Deaf. The program provides general support and funds for construction and maintenance of facilities. The FY2014 and FY2015 appropriations were each $32 million. The appropriations for Gallaudet University and the National Technical Institute for the Deaf (NTID) were $119 million in FY2014 and $120 million in FY2015, and $66 million for FY2014 and $67 million for FY2015, respectively. The federal government exempts interest income earned on bonds issued by state, local, and tribal governments for a "public" purpose from federal income tax. The tax exemption for bonds issued by state and local governments benefits public projects like schools and roads by lowering the cost of capital. Tax Credit Bonds (TCBs) offer a federal tax credit to investors or a direct payment to issuers. Qualified Energy Conservation Bonds (QECBs) can be used to reduce energy consumption in public buildings. The Qualified Zone Academy Bonds (QZABs) can be used by state and local governments for school renovation, equipment, teacher training, and course materials, excluding construction. There is no statutory deadline for eligible public entities to issue the national bond volume cap for QECBs of $3.2 billion, allocated by the U.S. Department of the Treasury to states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. possessions. States must reallocate a portion of their allocation to large local governments, including Indian tribal governments. The Qualified Zone Academy Bonds (QZABs) require public schools to meet specific criteria, including being located in designated areas or having a high percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-price lunches. Schools must collaborate with businesses, receive a match from private entities, and have an approved education plan. The national bond volume cap for QZABs is $400 million for each of CY2012 and CY2013, with unused credit capacity carryover allowed for up to two years. Qualified School Construction Bonds (QSCBs) provide funding for school facility construction, rehabilitation, or land acquisition, excluding charter schools. The authority to issue Qualified School Construction Bonds (QSCBs) expired in 2010, but Treasury allocated $200 million each in 2009 and 2010 to the U.S. Department of the Interior for Indian tribal governments to construct or repair BIE-funded schools. State and local governments can issue tax-exempt bonds for qualified public educational facilities, benefiting from lower interest rates due to the tax-exempt status. Indian tribal governments generally cannot issue tax-exempt private activity bonds. The Qualified School Construction Bonds (QSCBs) expired in 2010. Treasury allocated $200 million each in 2009 and 2010 to the U.S. Department of the Interior for Indian tribal governments to construct or repair BIE-funded schools. State and local governments can issue tax-exempt bonds for qualified public educational facilities, benefiting from lower interest rates. Indian tribal governments generally cannot issue tax-exempt private activity bonds. A public educational facility is a public school facility constructed through a public-private partnership agreement. Bonds for these facilities do not count against a state's private-activity volume cap. The Hispanic-Serving Institutions Education Grants Program supports Hispanic-serving IHEs in attracting, retaining, and graduating students pursuing careers in food and agricultural sciences. Funds may be used for minor alterations, renovations, or repairs related to the grant's major purpose. Land-grant colleges, established in 1862 by the Morrill Act, receive federal funds for research and extension activities. The 1862, 1890, and 1994 land-grant institutions benefit from these funds. The Hatch Act of 1887 supports agricultural research at the 1862 colleges, allowing for construction and renovation of facilities. The Hatch Act provides funds for land purchase, building construction, and research activities. The Evans-Allen Research program and 1890 Facilities Grants program allocate funds for agricultural research and facility improvements at 1890 land-grant institutions like Tuskegee University and West Virginia State University. Appropriations for these programs were $244 million and $44 million in FY2014 and FY2015, respectively. The Tribal Colleges Endowment Fund supports education in agricultural sciences for Native Americans by enhancing educational capacity at tribal colleges through various means. This includes curricula design, faculty development, equipment for teaching, and facility support. Appropriations for the fund were $12 million in each of FY2014 and FY2015. The Tribal Colleges Education Equity Program and Tribal Colleges Extension Program received appropriations of $3 million each in FY2014 and FY2015. These programs support the capacity of 1994 institutions to enhance educational opportunities for Native Americans in agricultural sciences and provide culturally relevant extension education programs to the public. Funds can be used for minor alterations, renovations, or repairs with prior approval. The USDA Community Facilities Loans and Grants program provides funding for construction, improvement, and essential services for rural community facilities. Eligible entities include state and local governments, tribes, and nonprofit organizations. Loan authorization levels are $1.5 billion for direct loans. In FY2014, loan authorization levels were $1.5 billion for direct loans and $60 million for guaranteed loans. The Secure Rural Schools (SRS) Payments compensate counties for federal lands' tax-exempt status. Forest Service payments are allocated for roads and schools in counties with national forests. The Secure Rural Schools (SRS) Payments, totaling $281 million in FY2014, compensate counties for federal lands' tax-exempt status. State laws dictate the allocation of payments for road and school programs, with varying percentages allocated for school programs. The Bureau of Land Management payments can be used for any local governmental purpose. The Economic Development Administration administers a grant program to fund public works investments for job creation and regional competitiveness. Indian tribes and nonprofit IHEs are eligible to apply for these grants. The Economic Development Administration allocates funds for projects promoting regional competitiveness. Indian tribes and nonprofit IHEs can apply for grants based on economic distress criteria. The program received $96 million in FY2014 and $99 million in FY2015. Congress appropriates funds for NIST buildings and university research facilities. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2008 created a grant program for new research science buildings. The Department of Defense provides funds to LEAs serving military-connected children through the Impact Aid program. This includes the Impact Aid Supplemental program, Impact Aid for Large Scale Rebasing (BRAC) program, and Impact Aid for Children with Severe Disabilities program. The Construction of Research Facilities grant program allocates funds for scientific research at IHEs and nonprofit organizations. The Impact Aid for Children with Severe Disabilities program provides reimbursement to LEAs for costs related to educating children with severe disabilities. Funding for this program was $40 million in FY2014 and $25 million in FY2015. Additionally, the Department of Defense allocates funds for construction and renovation of schools on military installations to address capacity and facility deficiencies. The FY2015 appropriation for this purpose was $175 million. The Department of Defense allocates funds for major construction and replacement projects for schools on military installations. The Defense-wide military construction appropriations support operations, maintenance, and facilities for institutions of higher education. The State Energy Program provides grants to states and territories for energy efficiency and renewable energy initiatives, with appropriations of $50 million each for FY2014 and FY2015. The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) funds construction activities for Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) schools and school facilities with appropriations of $9 billion each for FY2014 and FY2015. The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) funds construction activities for Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) schools and school facilities in 23 states. The construction activities include new school facilities, employee and student housing, and facilities improvement and repair. The FY2014 and FY2015 appropriations for education construction were $55 million and $75 million, respectively. The Historic Preservation Fund (HPF) was established to protect significant cultural and historic resources, providing matching grants to state and tribal historic preservation offices. The National Park Service administers grant programs providing $56 million in FY2014 and FY2015 to state and tribal historic preservation offices. Payments in Lieu of Taxes (PILT) compensate local governments for reductions in property tax bases due to federally owned land. PILT payments are calculated under a complex formula and can be used for any governmental purpose, including school facilities. The FY2014 and FY2015 appropriations for grants under various acts totaled $437 million and $405 million, respectively. These grants support tribally controlled colleges and universities, postsecondary education programs, and scholarships for Indian students. The Public Assistance Grant Program (PA Program) is administered by FEMA to provide assistance for various governmental purposes. The Public Assistance Grant Program (PA Program) is administered by FEMA under the Stafford Act. Grants are available for states and communities with disaster declarations, for debris removal, emergency measures, and building repairs. Eligible applicants include various governmental entities and nonprofits. The Public Assistance Grant Program (PA Program) provides grants for debris removal, emergency measures, and building repairs to eligible applicants such as public and private nonprofit schools and IHEs. School facilities of religious institutions are also eligible if primarily used for secular education. Grants can be used to replace damaged school supplies and equipment, including advanced laboratory and research equipment for IHEs. The Hazard Mitigation Grant Program (HMGP) offers grants for states, local governments, school districts, tribal governments, and certain nonprofits, including IHEs, to implement mitigation measures. The Hazard Mitigation Grant Program (HMGP) provides funds for states, local governments, school districts, tribal governments, and certain nonprofits, including IHEs, to implement long-term hazard mitigation measures after a major disaster declaration. Allowable activities include acquiring real property and retrofitting structures to minimize damages from natural hazards. FEMA awarded $812 million in FY2012 and $472 million in FY2013 under HMGP. Amounts for HMGP are derived from a percentage of total disaster spending and cost-shared on a 75% federal/25% state and local basis. The Institute of American Indian and Alaska Native Culture and Arts Development is a federally chartered independent nonprofit educational institution dedicated to the study, preservation, and care of Indian arts and culture. Appropriations may be used for the institution's operation and capital improvements. The Institute of American Indian and Alaska Native Culture and Arts Development received approximately $9 million in funding for FY2014 and FY2015. The Office of Challenge Grants supports humanities education through grants for equipment, technology, facilities, staffing, programming, and endowments for eligible nonprofit organizations. The program received $8 million in FY2014 and $9 million in FY2015 for grants. Various acronyms were mentioned such as ARRA, BIE, ED, ESEA, FEMA, HBCU, HEA, IHE, K-12, LEA, P.L., QECB, QSCB, QZAB, and U.S.C.
